$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 1-trityl-midazol (Compound 28, Scheme 19) was prepared by adding Et3N
(5.1 ml, 36.7 mmol) at 0 °C to a stirred solution of the imidazole
Compound 27 (2.5 grams, 36.7 mmol) dissolved in 75 ml DMF. After 30
minutes of stirring, trityl-chloride (10.3 grams, 36.7 mmol) dissolved in
DMF (45 ml) was added slowly to the reaction mixture, and the reaction
mixture was allowed to reach room temperature while stirred continuously
for over night. Thereafter the reaction mixture was quenched with cold
water (1 L) to precipitate a solid, which was collected by filtration and
recrystallized from hexane/DCM to afford Compound 28 as a white solid (91
% yield). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) - δ: 7.47 (s, 1H), 7.33-7.30 (m, 9H),
7.16-7.12 (m, 6H), 7.07 (s, 1H), 6.83 (s, 1H).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 3. Preparation of imidazole derivatives The Lewis bases imidazole were
prepared according to the literature method (Scheme S4).6 A solution of
2-substituted imidazole derivative (0.02 mol) and triethyl amine (8.30
mL, 0.06 mol) in 20 mL of chloroform was added to an ice-cooled solution
of triphenylchloromethane (6.13 g, 0.022 mol) in 15 mL of chloroform.
After the reaction mixture was stirred for 1 h at ambient temperature, it
was washed twice with 15 mL portions of a 0.5 M HCl solution, and then
washed once with 15 mL of a saturated NaHCO3 solution. The organic layer
was dried over Na2SO4 and evaporated in vacuo. The residue was purified
by column chromatography on silica gel using CH2Cl2/MeOH (10:1) as the
mobile phase to give the afforded the crude product. Recrystallization
from acetic ether gave the pure product and more or less according to the
R substituent. White solid, yield 90%. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ 7.47
(s, 1H), 7.34-7.32 (m, 9H), 7.15-7.13 (m, 6H), 7.07 (s, 1H), 6.83 (s,
1H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz): δ 142.59, 139.09, 129.85, 128.44, 128.09,
128.08, 121.76, 75.27. HRMS (m/z): Calcd. for [C22H19N2]+: 311.1548,
found: 311.1549.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM literature preparation
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Mechanistic Understanding of Dinuclear Cobalt(III) Complex Mediated
Highly Enantioselective Copolymerization of meso-Epoxides with CO2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Macromolecules (Washington, DC, United States) (2014), 47(22), 7775-7788

$DATUM 91
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 584-08-7
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1017605-84-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Experimental Procedure of N-Arylation
Under Homogeneous Conditions Catalyst 1f (0.007 g, 1 mol%), K2CO3 (0.276
g, 2 mmol) were added to a mixture of 1-chloro-4-nitrobenzene (0.158 g, 1
mmol) and imidazole (0.081 g, 1.2 mmol) in 3 mL of DMF. The reaction
mixture was heated at 110 °C under stirring for 1.5 h. After cooling to
ambient temperature, the resulting mixture was added with 4 mL of ethyl
acetate and 10 mL of water. The organic layer was separated, and the
aqueous layer was further extracted with ethyl acetate (10 mL). The
combined organic phase was washed with brine and dried over Na2SO4. The
solvent was removed under vacuum, and the residue was further purified by
flash-column chromatography on silica gel to afford the product
1-(4-nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole in 94% yield. Table 4, Entry 2, yield 91%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM N-Arylation of heterocycles with chloro- and fluoroarenes using
resin-supported sulfonato-Cu(salen) complex
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kantam, M. Lakshmi; Ramani, T.; Chakrapani, L.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2008), 38(4), 626-636

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Experimental Procedure of N-Arylation
under Heterogeneous Conditions Catalyst 1f (0.050 g, 1 mol%) and K2CO3
(0.276 g, 2 mmol) were added to a mixture of 1-chloro-4-nitrobenzene
(0.158 g, 1 mmol) and imidazole (0.081 g, 1.2 mmol) in 4 mL of DMF. The
reaction mixture was heated at 110 °C under stirring for 4 h. After
cooling to ambient temperature, the resulting mixture was filtered off.
and the catalyst was washed several times with water and ethyl acetate to
remove any excess reagents and reused for the other cycle. The filtrate
was extracted with water, and the organic layer was dried over Na2SO4.
This was concentrated under vacuum, and the residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel to afford the product
1-(4-nitro-phenyl)-1H-imidazole in 91% yield. Table 4, Entry 2, yield
90%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES

$DATUM 67-56-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General Procedure for N-Arylation of Imidazoles with Arylboronic Acid An
oven-dried, round-bottomed flask was charged with SiO2-NHC-CuI (0.05
mmol), imidazole (1.1 mmol), arylboronic acid (1.0 mmol), and CH3OH (3
mL). The mixture was stirred at 50 °C for 3 h under an atmosphere of air.
The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC. On completion of the
reaction, the mixture was filtered. The solution was concentrated under
reduced pressure and purified by column chromatography on silica gel
(hexane–EtOAc, 70:30). Corresponding pure N-arylated imidazole.
1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole[15]. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 7.57 (s, 1H),
7.45–7.41 (m, 2H), 7.34–7.30 (m, 3H), 7.23 (br s, 1H), 7.17 (br s, 1H);
13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 137.1, 135.3, 130.1, 129.7, 127.3, 121.3,
118.1.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, recyclable catalyst, silica used as solid
support, reaction performed under air atmosphere, optimization study,
optimized on solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM SiO2-NHC-CuI-catalyzed N-arylation of imidazoles with arylboronic acids
under base-free reaction conditions
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Liu, Ping; Li, Pinhua; Wang, Lei
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2012), 42(17), 2595-2605

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1317-39-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 92149-07-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-74-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the N-arylation of
imidazoles with aryl bromides. An oven-dried screw-cap test tube was
charged with Cu2O (0.05 mmol), L1c (0.15 mmol), imidazole (1.2 mmol),
aryl bromide (1.00 mmol, if solid), poly(ethylene glycol) (200 mg),
Cs2CO3 (1.4 mmol), and a magnetic stir bar. The reaction vessel was
fitted with a rubber septum. The vessel was evacuated and back-filled
with argon or nitrogen, and this sequence was repeated an additional
time. Aryl bromide (1.00 mmol, if liquid), and solvent (0.5 mL) were then
added successively. The reaction tube was sealed, immersed, and stirred
in a preheated oil bath for the designated time period. The reaction
mixture was cooled to room temperature, diluted with dichloromethane (10
mL), filtered through a plug of celite, and eluted with additional
dichloromethane (50 mL). The filtrate was concentrated and the resulting
residue was purified by flash chromatography to provide the desired
product. 1-(4-tert-Butyl-phenyl)-1H-imidazole14 (2a)
1-(4-Imidazol-1-yl-phenyl)-ethanone (2g) The general procedure was
followed using Cu2O (7.2 mg, 0.05 mmol), L1c (36 mg, 0.15 mmol), PEG (200
mg), Cs2CO3 (0.45 g, 1.4 mmol), 4-bromoacetophenone (199 mg, 1.00 mmol),
and imidazole (82 mg, 1.2 mmol) with butyronitrile (0.4 mL) as solvent
for 48 h at 110 °C. Chromatographic purification (hexane / ethyl acetate
1 : 3) afforded 1-(4-imidazol-1-yl-phenyl)-ethanone (white solid, 159 mg,
86%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.04, (m, 2H), 7.92 (bs, 1H), 7.46 (m,
2H), 7.33 (bs, 1H), 7.19 (bs, 1H), 2.59 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3)
δ 196.6, 140.7, 135.7, 135.4, 131.2, 130.4, 120.7, 117.8, 26.7. m.p.
112-114 °C (Lit. 110-112 °C).19
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Copper-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Imidazoles and Benzimidazoles
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Altman, Ryan A.; Koval, Erica D.; Buchwald, Stephen L.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 72(16), 6190-6199

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME6 STEP1

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 1-(2-Nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole (2e); Typical
Procedure. A mixture of 1-chloro-2-nitrobenzene (1 mmol), 1H-imidazole
(1.2 mmol), K2CO3 (1.2 mmol), and Cu/Al-HTB (100 mg, 2.5 mol%) in DMF (2
mL) was stirred in a round-bottomed flask at 100 °C. When the reaction
was complete (TLC), the catalyst was filtered washed several times with
DMF, H2O and acetone and reused for the next reaction. DMF was removed
from the reaction filtrate under reduced pressure and crude material was
purified by chromatography (silica gel, 60-120 mesh, hexane-EtOAc) to
afford 2e.11 Product 2d. Yield 90%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry-catalyst
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

N(H)-heterocyclic amines

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the synthesis of
lipophilic zoledronate analogs (2-16): A mixture of imidazole (100 mmol),
alkyl bromide (100 mmol) and K2CO3 (200 mmol) in acetone (200 mL) was
refluxed overnight. Upon filtration and removal of solvent, the residue
was subjected to flash chromatography with ethyl acetate as eluant to
give product Yield &gt; 90 %.

$DATUM 90
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 3473-84-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Procedure for the Aza-Michael Reaction
of Amines with α,β-Unsaturated Carbonyls or Nitriles In a typical
procedure, catalyst (5 mol%) was added to a mixture of α,β-unsaturated
olefin (1.2mmol) and amine (1mmol) and stirred at room temperature. After
completion of reaction (as monitored by TLC), the reaction mixture was
diluted with ether, and the catalyst was centrifuged and washed with
ether. The combined organic layer was concentrated to give the crude
product. Column chromatography was performed using silica gel (60-120
mesh) to afford the pure β-amino adduct. The products were characterized
by comparison of their 1H NMR, IR, mass spectra, and elemental analysis
with those of authentic samples.[20,24] Table 2 Entry 10, yield 90%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM aza-Michael reaction, no solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DATUM Trivedi, Rajiv; Lalitha, P.; Roy, Sarabindu
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2008), 38(20), 3556-3566

$DATUM 288-32-4
$DTYPE RXN:PRO(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 25700-14-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-172-CAS-6964393
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 90
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 865-47-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1309-37-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole (3a); Typical Procedure
for 3a-g and 3a-7a. To a 25-mL, round-bottom flask with side arm,
containing magnetic stirring bar equipped with an air condenser (without
water circulation), were added Fe2O3 (16 mg, 10 mol%), imidazole (1, 68
mg, 1 mmol), t-BuOK (224 mg, 2 mmol), DMSO (3 mL), and iodobenzene (2a,
408 mg, 2 mmol) in an open atmosphere. The contents were stirred for 24 h
at 120 °C and allowed to cool to 25 °C . The mixture was diluted with
EtOAc (5 mL) and H2O (5 mL) and stirring was continued for a further 10
min. The organic layer was separated and the aqueous layer was extracted
with EtOAc (3 × 10 mL). The combined organic extracts were washed with
H2O and brine soln and dried (anhyd Na2SO4). The solvent was evaporated
and the residue was purified by column chromatography (silica gel 100-200
mesh, EtOAc-hexanes, 1:1). 2-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)pyridine (3g).
Light-yellow oil; yield: 130 mg (90%). FTIR (neat): 3117, 2592, 1670,
1597, 1304, 1055, 904 cm-1. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 7.21-7.29 (m, 2
H), 7.36-7.38 (m, 1 H), 7.65-7.66 (m, 1 H), 7.81-7.86 (m, 2 H), 8.36 (d,
1 H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 112.3, 116.1, 121.9, 130.7, 134.9,
138.9, 149.1. LC-MS (EI): m/z = 146 (M + 1).

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the synthesis of
lipophilic zoledronate analogs (2-16): A mixture of imidazole (100 mmol),
alkyl bromide (100 mmol) and K2CO3 (200 mmol) in acetone (200 mL) was
refluxed overnight. Upon filtration and removal of solvent, the residue
was subjected to flash chromatography with ethyl acetate as eluant to
give product Yield &gt; 90 %.

$DATUM 174501-65-6
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 2.4. General Procedure for the Aza-Michael
Reaction of Imidazole with α,β-Unsaturated Compounds Using Cu(acac)2in
Ionic Liquids. To the solution of Cu(acac)2 (0.005 g, 2 mol %) in ionic
liquid (1 mL), imidazole (1 mmol) and α,β-unsaturated compound (1.2 mmol)
were added and stirred at 60°C for the appropriate time (see Table 2,
presented later in this paper). After completion of the reaction, as
indicated by TLC, the product was extracted with a 1:1 ethyl
acetate:n-hexane mixture (3 x 10 mL). The combined organic extracts were
concentrated under reduced pressure and purified by column chromatography
on silica gel to afford the pure product. The recovered ionic liquid
phase that contained Cu(acac)2 was dried under reduced pressure for the
next runs. The products were characterized by comparison of their nuclear
magnetic resonance (NMR) and mass spectra with those reported in the
literature. 24,26,39 entry 2, yield 90%
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM aza-Michael reaction, ionic liquid used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Aza-Michael Addition of Imidazoles to α,β-Unsaturated Compounds and
Synthesis of β-Amino Alcohols via Nucleophilic Ring Opening of Epoxides
Using Copper(II) Acetylacetonate (Cu(acac)2) Immobilized in Ionic Liquids
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

Rajashree
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research (2007), 46(25), 8614-8619

$DATUM 7787-70-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Experimental Procedure for the
Solvent-Free Copper- Catalyzed N-Arylation of Imidazoles. A mixture of
imidazole 1 (1.0 mmol), aryl halide 2 (1.2 mmol), CuBr (10 mol %),
2-aminopyrimidine-4,6-diol (L1, 20 mol %), and TBAF (3 mmol) was stirred
at 145-150 °C for 24 h until complete consumption of starting material
was monitored by TLC. After the reaction was finished, ethyl acetate was
poured into the mixture, then washed with water, extracted with diethyl
ether, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and evaporated under vacuum, and the
residue was purified by flash column chromatography (ethyl acetate or
hexane/ethyl acetate) to afford the desired product.
2-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidine (6) White solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3)
δ: 8.72 (d, J = 4.8 Hz, 2H), 8.64 (s, 1H), 7.92 (s, 1H), 7.23 (t, J = 4.8
Hz, 1H), 7.19 (s, 1H); 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3) δ:158.7, 156.3, 136.2,
130.7, 118.8, 116.5; LRMS (EI, 20 eV) m/z (%): 146 (M+, 100).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM no solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM 2-Aminopyrimidine-4,6-diol as an efficient ligand for solvent-free
copper-catalyzed N-arylations of imidazoles with aryl and heteroaryl
halides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Xie, Ye-Xiang; Pi, Shao-Feng; Wang, Jian; Yin, Du-Lin; Li, Jin-Heng
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2006), 71(21), 8324-8327

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Boc2O (1.0 mmol) was added to a mixture of
phenol or amine (1.0 mmol) and MgBr2·OEt2 (0.1 mmol) in a round-bottom
flask, at which point an evolution of gas occurs, and the reaction
mixture was stirred magnetically at room temperature(if necessary,
reactions was heated to ∼60°C). After complete consumption of the phenol
or amine(by thin-layer chromatography, TLC; 3-16 h), the reaction mixture
was diluted with water and extracted with EtOAc(3×20 mL), and the
combined EtOAc extracts were dried with Na2SO4 and concentrated under
vacuum rotary evaporation. The residue was isolated by column
chromatography through a bed of silica gel and eluted with 5-30%ethyl
acetate in hexane to afford the desired Bocprotected product. tert-Butyl
3H-imidazole-1-carboxylate 14 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ ppm 1.56 (s, 9 H)
6.96 (s, 1 H) 7.31 (s, 1 H) 8.01 (s, 1 H); 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3) δ ppm
28.21, 85.95, 117.47, 130.51, 137.41, 147.44.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry, green chemistry-catalyst, no solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM MgBr2·OEt2: A Lewis Acid Catalyst for the O- and N-Boc Protection of
Phenols and Amines
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Schechter, Aaron; Goldrich, David; Chapman, Jessica R.; Uberheide,
Beatrix M.; Lim, Daniel
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2015), 45(5), 653-660

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole (3a); Typical Procedure
for 3a-g and 3a-7a. To a 25-mL, round-bottom flask with side arm,
containing magnetic stirring bar equipped with an air condenser (without
water circulation), were added Fe2O3 (16 mg, 10 mol%), imidazole (1, 68
mg, 1 mmol), t-BuOK (224 mg, 2 mmol), DMSO (3 mL), and iodobenzene (2a,
408 mg, 2 mmol) in an open atmosphere. The contents were stirred for 24 h
at 120 °C and allowed to cool to 25 °C . The mixture was diluted with
EtOAc (5 mL) and H2O (5 mL) and stirring was continued for a further 10
min. The organic layer was separated and the aqueous layer was extracted
with EtOAc (3 × 10 mL). The combined organic extracts were washed with
H2O and brine soln and dried (anhyd Na2SO4). The solvent was evaporated
and the residue was purified by column chromatography (silica gel 100-200
mesh, EtOAc-hexanes, 1:1). yellow oil; yield: 129 mg (90%). FTIR (neat):
3113, 1956, 1873, 1674, 1601, 1512, 1249 cm-1. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ
= 7.22 (s, 1 H), 7.29-7.30 (m, 1 H), 7.37-7.41 (m, 3 H), 7.47-7.51 (m, 2
H), 7.87 (s, 1 H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 118.2, 121.5, 127.5,
129.9, 130.4, 135.6, 137.4. LC-MS (EI): m/z = 143 (M-1).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM alternative preparation shown, optimized on
agent,catalyst,solvent,temperature, optimization study
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Simple and convenient methods for N-arylation of heterocycles and
diphenylamine
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Alakonda, Laxhmaiah; Periasamy, Mariappan
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2012), 44(7), 1063-1068

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the N-arylation of
nitrogen nucleophiles Imidazole (163.4 mg, 2.40 mmol), 38.1 mg CuI (0.20
mmol), 143.4 mg 1,4-bis(2-hydroxy-5-methoxybenzyl)piperazine (0.40 mmol),
aryl halide (2.00 mmol), 225 mg KOH (4.0 mmol), 64.4 mg (n-Bu)4NBr (0.20
mmol), and 2 cm 3 water were put into a Teflon septum screw-capped tube
and then sealed in the air. The reaction mixture was stirred at 120 °C
for 12 h. After cooling to room temperature, ethyl acetate (3 x 1 cm3)
was added to extract the coupling product and results were determined by
GC. The pure N-arylated product was obtained by column chromatography on
silica gel. All products were known and characterized by 1H NMR
spectroscopy, the data were found to be identical with those reported in
the literature. 1-phenyl-1H-imidazole[1] (3a) Following the general
produce, using 1H-imidazole (163 mg, 2.4 mmol) and iodobenzene (408 mg, 2
mmol) provided 260 mg ( 90% yield) of the coupling product as a yellow
oil after purification by flash chromatography (eluent: petrol
ether/ethyl acetate = 3/1). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 7.86 (s, 1H),
7.46-7.50 (m, 2H), 7.35-7.40 (m, 3H), 7.29 (br s, 1H), 7.21 (br s, 1H)
ppm. MS ( EI , M/Z): 144 [M+], 117, 90, 77.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry, green chemistry (protocol), green chemistry-solvent,
sealed tube used, alternative preparation shown
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

of imidazoles in water
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Monatshefte fuer Chemie (2010), 141(9), 1009-1013

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure A: Iron-Copper co-catalyzed
cross-coupling reaction (CuO and Fe(acac)3; 1 mmol and 2 mmol scale)
After standard cycles of evacuation and back-filling with dry and pure
nitrogen, an oven-dried Radley tube (Carousel "reaction stations
RR98030") equipped with a magnetic stirring bar is charged with CuO (0.1
eq.), Fe(acac)3 (0.3 eq.), the nucleophile (1.5eq.), CS2CO3 (2 eq.) and
the aryl halide (1 eq.), if a solid. The tube is evacuated, back-filled
with nitrogen. If a liquid, the aryl reagent is added under a stream of
nitrogen by syringe at room temperature, followed by anhydrous and
degassed DMF (1.0 mL). The tube is sealed under a positive pressure of
nitrogen, stirred and heated to 90 or 125 °C or 140 °C for the required
time period. After cooling to room temperature, the mixture is diluted
with dichloromethane (~ 20 mL) and filtered through a plug of celite®,
the filter cake being further washed with dichloromethane (~ 5 mL). The
filtrate is washed twice with water (~ 10 mL x 2). Gathered aqueous
phases are twice extracted with dichloromethane (~ 10 mL). Organic layers
are gathered, dried over Na2SO4, filtered and concentrated in vacuo to
yield the crude product which is then purified by silica gel
chromatography with an eluent of hexanes and dichloromethane. The
products are characterized by NMR, IR and mass spectra with those of
authentic samples. 1-phenyl-1H-imidazole, Following General Procedure A
(90 °C, 30 hours), 1H-imidazole (102 mg, 1.5mmol) is coupled with
iodo-benzene (112 μL, 1.0mmol). The s crude brown oil is purified by
flash chromatography on silica gel (eluent: hexane/ethylacetate = 20/80)
to provide 130 mg, 90 % isolated yield) of the desired product as a light
yellow oil. Yield 130 mg, 90 % 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.81 (s, 1H,
H9), 7.40-7.43 (m, 2H, H3,5), 7.28- 7.34 (m, 3H, H2,4,6), 7.22 (s, 1H,
H7), 7.15 (s, 1H, H8). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 137.35 (C1), 135.59
(C9), 130.32 (C8), 129.92 (63,5), 127.56 (C4), 121.53(C2,6), 118.32(C7).
IR (KBr): (cm-1) = 3115, 3067, 1600, 1509, 1304, 1247, 1112, 1057, 962,
905,815,759,692,658,520. GC/MS: rt = 16.16 min, M/Z = 144. HRMS: 145.0768
(M+H). Theoretical: 145.0766.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM sealed tube used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Iron-copper cocatalyzed process for carbon-carbon or carbon-heteroatom
bonding
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Taillefer, Marc; Xia, Ning; Ouali, Armelle
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2008004088 A2 2008-01-10

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 2.2 Typical Experimental Procedure A mixture
of aryl halide (1 mmol), nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.5 mmol), Cu2O
(0.1 mmol), KOH (2 mmol) and DMSO (2 mL) was stirred at the temperature
specified under Ar atmosphere until nearly complete conversion of aryl
halide as monitored by GC or TLC, the cooled mixture was partitioned
between ethyl acetate (10 mL) and water (3 mL). The organic layer was
separated, and the aqueous layer was extracted with ethyl acetate (5 mL).
The combined organic layers were washed with brine (5 mL), dried over
Na2SO4, and concentrated to give the crude product, which was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel (200–300 mesh) using ethyl
acetate/methanol as eluent. Entry: 2 Yield: 90%
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Cu2O: a Simple and Efficient Reusable Catalyst for N-arylation of
Nitrogen-containing Heterocycles with Aryl Halides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Huang, Yi-Zheng; Miao, Hong; Zhang, Qiao-Hong; Chen, Chen; Xu, Jie
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Catalysis Letters (2008), 122(3-4), 344-348

$DATUM 174501-65-6
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 2.4. General Procedure for the Aza-Michael Reaction of Imidazole with
α,β-Unsaturated Compounds Using Cu(acac)2in Ionic Liquids. To the
solution of Cu(acac)2 (0.005 g, 2 mol %) in ionic liquid (1 mL),
imidazole (1 mmol) and α,β-unsaturated compound (1.2 mmol) were added and
stirred at 60°C for the appropriate time (see Table 2, presented later in
this paper). After completion of the reaction, as indicated by TLC, the
product was extracted with a 1:1 ethyl acetate:n-hexane mixture (3 x 10
mL). The combined organic extracts were concentrated under reduced
pressure and purified by column chromatography on silica gel to afford
the pure product. The recovered ionic liquid phase that contained
Cu(acac)2 was dried under reduced pressure for the next runs. The
products were characterized by comparison of their nuclear magnetic
resonance (NMR) and mass spectra with those reported in the literature.
24,26,39 entry 1, yield 90%
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM aza-Michael reaction, ionic liquid used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Aza-Michael Addition of Imidazoles to α,β-Unsaturated Compounds and
Synthesis of β-Amino Alcohols via Nucleophilic Ring Opening of Epoxides
Using Copper(II) Acetylacetonate (Cu(acac)2) Immobilized in Ionic Liquids
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Typical Experimental Procedure for the Solvent-Free Copper- Catalyzed
N-Arylation of Imidazoles. A mixture of imidazole 1 (1.0 mmol), aryl
halide 2 (1.2 mmol), CuBr (10 mol %), 2-aminopyrimidine-4,6-diol (L1, 20
mol %), and TBAF (3 mmol) was stirred at 145-150 °C for 24 h until
complete consumption of starting material was monitored by TLC. After the
reaction was finished, ethyl acetate was poured into the mixture, then
washed with water, extracted with diethyl ether, dried over anhydrous
Na2SO4, and evaporated under vacuum, and the residue was purified by
flash column chromatography (ethyl acetate or hexane/ethyl acetate) to
afford the desired product. 1-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-1H-imidazole (3) White
solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 7.76 (s, 1H), 7.28 (d, J = 9.2 Hz, 2H),
7.19 (d, J = 9.6 Hz, 2H), 6.97 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 3.83 (s, 3H); 13C NMR
(100 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 158.5, 135.5, 130.3, 129.7, 122.8, 118.5, 114.6,
55.3; LRMS (EI, 20 eV) m/z (%): 174 (M+, 100).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM optimization study, yield depends on reaction conditions, no solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM 2-Aminopyrimidine-4,6-diol as an efficient ligand for solvent-free
copper-catalyzed N-arylations of imidazoles with aryl and heteroaryl
halides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 90
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 584-08-7
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7681-65-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 25322-68-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Coupling Reaction A
Schlenk tube with a magnetic stirring bar was charged with imidazole (2.4
mmol), K2CO3 (4.2 mmol), CuI (0.16 mmol, 10 mol%), aryl halide (2.0
mmol), and PEG (3 mL). The tube was sealed after being evacuated twice
and back filled with N2. The mixture was stirred at 110°C for 24 h,
cooled to room temperature, and extracted with diethyl ether (5×10mL).
The upper layers were decanted, combined, and concentrated to the crude
product, which was analyzed by GC-MS. The PEG phase of the lower layer
was subjected to a second run with the same substrates. Further
purification of the product was achieved by flash chromatography on a
silica-gel column. All the products, which are known compounds, were
characterized and compared with authentic compounds previously reported
in the literatures.[9a,9b,12,15] Entry 5; Yield 90%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Efficient and Reusable Catalytic System of CuI-PEG for N-Arylation of
Imidazoles
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhang, Qiang; Luo, Jun; Wei, Yunyang
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2012), 42(1), 114-121

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Procedure B: Coupling of Aryl halides
with Amides, Imidazoles, Phenols or Thiols. (Table 2, entry 4): An
oven-dried Schlenk tube equipped with a Teflon valve was charged with a
magnetic stir bar, Cs2CO3 (684 mg, 2.1 mmol), CuBr (15 mg, 0.10 mmol, 10
mol%), and ethyl 2-oxocyclohexanecarboxylate (34 mg, 0.20 mmol, 20 mol%)
The tube was evacuated and backfilled with N2 (this procedure was
repeated three times). Under a counter flow of N2, DMSO (0.5 mL) was
added by syringe at room temperature (25-30 °C) and pre-stirred for 0.5
h. Then a solution of 1-iodo-4-methylbenzene (218 mg, 1.0 mmol),
2-pyrrolidinone (102 mg, 1.2 mmol) in DMSO (0.5 mL) was added via syringe
under a counter flow of N2. The tube was sealed and the mixture was
allowed to stir for 24 h at 60 ºC. The reaction mixture was directly
passed through celite. After rinsed with further 60 mL of ethyl acetate,
the combined filtrate was washed by saturated brine (10 ml × 2). After
the organic layer was dried by Na2SO4, it was concentrated by rotatory
evaporation. The residue was purified bycolumn chromatography on silica
gel using hexane/ethyl acetate (1:1) as eluent to give a white solid of
1-p-tolylpyrrolidin-2-one (151 mg, 86 %). 1d, 1-p-tolylpyrrolidin-2-one4
(Table 2, entry 4, 10) 2d, 1-p-tolyl-1H-imidazole10 (Table 3, entry 4)
Procedure B was followed. Yellow solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.81
(1H, s), 7.25-7.28 (4H, m), 7.24 (1H, m), 7.19 (1H, s), 2.40 (3H, s); 13C
NMR(100 MHz, CDCl3) δ 137.3, 135.5, 134.9, 130.2, 130.1, 121.3, 118.2,
20.8 (CDCl3 δ 77.0).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DATUM Lv, Xin; Bao, Weiliang

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Typical Experimental Procedure: A mixture of 4-bromotoluene (1 mmol),
imidazole (1.2 mmol), K2CO3 (2 mmol) and Cu(II)-NaY (100 mg) in DMF (3
mL) was heated to 120 °C for the specified time (Table 2). The progress
of the reaction was monitored by GC or TLC. The reaction mixture was
filtered to separate the catalyst and the filtrate was quenched with aq
NaHCO3 and the product extracted with EtOAc. The combined organic layers
were washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4 and concentrated. The residue
was purified by column chromatography to afford pure
1-(4-methylphenyl)-1H-imidazole. Yield 90%. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ = 7.76 (br
s, 1 H), 7.24 (br s, 4 H), 7.19 (br s, 1 H), 7.13 (br s, 1 H), 2.39 (s, 3
H); MS (EI): m/z (%) = 158, 131, 104, 91 (100) 50; Anal. Calcd for
C10N2H10: C, 75.95; N, 17.72; H, 6.33. Found: C, 76.09; N, 17.75; H,
6.16.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Coupling of Styryl Bromides with Phenols,
Thiophenols, and Imidazoles; General Procedure An oven-dried Schlenk tube
was back-filled with N2 and charged with Cs2CO3 (650 mg, 2.0 mmol), CuI
(30 mg, 0.15 mmol, 15 mol%), ethyl 2-oxocyclohexanecarboxylate (50 mg,
0.30 mmol, 30 mol%), the appropriate (E)-β -bromostyrene (1 mmol), the
nucleophilic reagent (phenol, thiophenol, or imidazole for C-O, C-S, or
C-N coupling, respectively; 1.2 mmol), and anhyd solvent (2 mL) under a
stream of N2. The reaction tube was quickly sealed and the contents were
stirred at the temperature indicated in Tables 2-4 for 24 h. The cooled
reaction mixture was dissolved in H2O and extracted with EtOAc. The
combined organic layer was dried (MgSO4). The product was further
purified by column chromatography (silica gel, PE-EtOAc).
(E)-1-(4-Fluorostyryl)-1H-imidazole (Table 4, entry 4) Solid, yield 90%.
Mp 78-79 °C. IR (KBr): 3146, 3110, 3045, 2957, 1659, 1597, 1491, 1288,
931, 808 cm-1. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 7.75 (s, 1 H), 7.40-7.36 (m,
2 H), 7.30-7.26 (m, 2 H), 7.16 (s, 1 H), 7.09-7.05 (m, 2 H), 6.72 (d, J =
14.4 Hz, 1 H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 163.63, 161.11, 136.22,
130.40, 127.64, 127.55, 122.40, 117.63, 116.07, 115.91, 115.70. Anal.
Calcd for C11H9FN2: C, 70.20; H, 4.82; N, 14.88; Found: C, 70.18; H,
4.82; N, 14.93.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM stereoselective
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Mild copper(I) iodide/β-keto ester catalyzed coupling reactions of styryl
bromides with phenols, thiophenols, and imidazoles
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Bao, Weiliang; Liu, Yunyun; Lv, Xin
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2008), (12), 1911-1917

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM A mixture of imidazole (4.1 g, 60 mmol) and NaOH (2.4 g, 60 mmol) in DMSO
(30 mL) was heated at 60°C for 2 h, and then 1,12-dibromododecane (9.2 g,
28 mmol) was added. The mixture was maintained at 60°C for another 2 h.
Upon cooling to room temperature, the mixture was poured into 300 mL of
water. The white precipitate was collected, washed with water and dried
in vacuum. 7.6 g of product as a white solid. Yield: 90 %. 1H NMR (CDCl3,
400 MHz): δ 7.38 (s, 2H), 6.98 (s, 2H), 6.84 (s, 2H), 3.85 (t, 4H, J =
7.2 Hz), 1.69 (m, 4H), 1.22-1.17 (m, 16H). 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz): δ
137.02, 129.30, 118.73, 46.96, 31.01, 29.36, 29.31, 28.98, 26.47.
HR-ESI-MS: m/z calculated for [M+H]+ C18H31N4: 303.25432; found:
303.25420, error: 0.4 ppm.

$DATUM 67-56-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: A typical procedure for N-arylation of
imidazole with phenylboronic acids: In a typical experimental procedure,
CuFAP(100 mg) was added to a mixture of imidazole (1.2 mmol),
phenylboronic acid (1 mmol) in methanol (3 mL) at room temperature, and
the mixture was stirred for 6 h. The progress of the reaction was
monitored by TLC and on completion of the reaction, the reaction mixture
was filtered and the filtrate was concentrated under reduced pressure to
give the crude product. The crude product was purified by column
chromatography on silica gel (hexane/ethylacetate, 70/30).
1-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-1H-imidazole, yield 90%. 1H NMR (300MHz, CDCl3): δ
7.71 (s, 1H), 7.28 (d, 2H, J= 9.0Hz), 7.15 (bs, 1H), 7.11 (bs, 1H), 6.94
(d, 2H, J = 9.0 Hz), 3.83 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (CDCl3, 75 MHz): δ = 159.0,
135.8, 130, 130.8, 123 (2C), 118.5, 114.6, (2C), 55.2; EI-MS: 174 (100%),
159, 147, 132, 120, 77; IR: (thin film /neat): cm-1; 3415, 2928, 1675,
1520, 1464, 1302, 1250, 1181, 1113, 1059, 1029, 833, 764, 661, 614, 536.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM An Efficient Base-Free N-Arylation of Imidazoles and Amines with
Arylboronic Acids Using Copper-Exchanged Fluorapatite
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kantam, M. Lakshmi; Venkanna, Gopaldasu T.; Sridhar, Chidara; Sreedhar,
Bojja; Choudary, Boyapati M.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2006), 71(25), 9522-9524

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for N-arylation of nitrogen
nucleophiles: Imidazole (75.0 mg, 1.10 mmol), CuSO4·5H2O (25.0 mg, 0.1
mmol), 1,2-bis(2-pyridyl)-ethane-N,N’-dioxides (41.4 mg, 0.2 mmol), aryl
halide (1.00 mmol), Cs2CO3 (652 mg, 2.0 mmol) and water (3 mL) were put
into a Teflon septum screw-capped tube and then sealed in the air. The
reaction mixture was stirred at 120 °C for 24 h. After cooled to room
temperature, ethyl acetate was added to extract the coupling product and
results were determined by GC/MS. The pure N-arylated product was finally
obtained by column chromatography on silica gel. All the products were
confirmed by 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectroscopic analysis.
1-phenyl-1H-imidazole[1] (1) 1-(4-bromophenyl)-1H-imidazole[2] (2)
Following the general procedure using 1H-imidazole (75 mg, 1.1 mmol) and
4-bromoiodobenzene (282 mg, 1 mmol) provided 200 mg (90% yield) of the
coupling product as a white solid after purification by flash
chromatography (ethyl acetate/petrol ether =1/1). 1H NMR (400 MHz,
CDCl3): δ 7.83 (s, 1H), 7.56-7.79 (m, 2H), 7.13-7.27 (m, 3H), 7.10 (s,
1H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): 136.33, 135.44, 133.05, 130.76, 123.01,
120.94, 118.10. MS (EI, M/Z): 222 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Pyridine N-Oxides as Ligands in Cu-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Imidazoles in
Water
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Liang, Lei; Li, Zhengkai; Zhou, Xiangge
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Organic Letters (2009), 11(15), 3294-3297

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for N-Arylation of Imidazole
with Aryl Bromides. A Schlenk tube equipped with a Teflon stopcock are
charged with a magnetic stir bar, K2CO3 (572 mg, 2.1 mmol), CuI (0.38 mg,
0.20 mmol, 20 mol %), and per-6-amino- β -cyclodextrin (100 mg, 0.08
mmol, 8 mol %). DMSO (1 mL) was added at room temperature. Then a
solution of bromobenzene (188 mg, 1.2 mmol) and imidazole (68 mg, 1.0
mmol) in DMSO (1 mL) was added. The tube was sealed and the mixture was
allowed to stir for 24 h at 110°C. Water (5 mL) was added to the reaction
mixture after completion of the reaction. Then it was extracted with
ethyl acetate (3 × 20 mL) and the combined organic layers were dried with
anhydrous Na2SO4 and concentrated by vacuum. The residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel, using hexane/ethyl acetate (1:3) as
eluant, to give an oil of 1-phenylimidazole 4a (164 mg, 98%)
3-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)aniline (4h), yield 90% 1H NMR (300 MHz): 7.86 (bs,
1H), 7.29-7.15 (m, 3H), 6.81-6.64 (m, 3H), 4.05 (bs, 2H) 13C NMR (75
MHz): 147.5, 137.9, 135.6, 130.2, 129.5, 118.4, 113.5, 110.8, 107.2
GC-MS: m/z 158.9 (M+)
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM sealed tube used, Ullmann reaction
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Per-6-amino-β-cyclodextrin as an Efficient Supramolecular Ligand and Host
for Cu(I)-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Imidazole with Aryl Bromides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Suresh, Palaniswamy; Pitchumani, Kasi
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2008), 73(22), 9121-9124

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure C: Coupling of Aryl
Chrolides with Amines or N-Containing Heterocycles (5.0 mmol scale). An
oven-dried Schlenk tube equipped with a Teflon valve (Kontes) was charged
with a magnetic stir bar, CuBr (7.2 mg, 0.05 mmol, 1 mol %), the L5 (16
mg, 0.1 mmol, 2 mol %), and Cs2CO3 (3.25 g, 10.0 mmol). Any remaining
solids (amine and/or aryl chloride) were added at this point. The tube
was evacuated and backfilled with argon (this procedure was repeated
three times). Under a counter flow of argon, amine (7.5 mmol) (if
liquid), aryl chloride (5.0 mmol) (if liquid), and DMSO (5.0 mL) were
added by syringe. Finally, the tube was sealed and the mixture was heated
at the indicated temperature (110 °C) for the indicated period of time.
Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was allowed to cool to room
temperature and then was diluted with ethyl acetate and passed through a
fritted glass filter to remove the inorganic salts, then solvent was
removed with the aid of a rotary evaporator. The residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel and the product was dried under
vacuum for at least 1 h. 4-(1H-Imidazole-1-yl)benzonitrile (7g/5l):5c
Following procedure C, 4-chlorobenzonitrile (690 mg, 5.0 mmol) was
allowed to react with 1H-imidazole (510 mg, 7.5 mmol) for 20 h at 110 °C.
The crude brown oil was purified by flash chromatography on silica gel to
provide 90% yield of the desired product as a white solid. 1H NMR (400
MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.96 (s, 1H), 7.82 (m, 2H), 7.55 (m, 2H), 7.35 (d, J= 1.2
Hz, 1H), 7.23 (d, J= 2.0 Hz, 1H) ppm.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM chemoselective, sealed tube used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Ligands for Copper-Catalyzed C-N Bond Forming Reactions with 1 Mol% CuBr
as Catalyst
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Yang, Kai; Qiu, Yatao; Li, Zheng; Wang, Zhaoyang; Jiang, Sheng
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2011), 76(9), 3151-3159

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Experimental Procedure of N-Arylation
Under Homogeneous Conditions Catalyst 1f (0.007 g, 1 mol%), K2CO3 (0.276
g, 2 mmol) were added to a mixture of 1-chloro-4-nitrobenzene (0.158 g, 1
mmol) and imidazole (0.081 g, 1.2 mmol) in 3 mL of DMF. The reaction
mixture was heated at 110 °C under stirring for 1.5 h. After cooling to
ambient temperature, the resulting mixture was added with 4 mL of ethyl
acetate and 10 mL of water. The organic layer was separated, and the
aqueous layer was further extracted with ethyl acetate (10 mL). The
combined organic phase was washed with brine and dried over Na2SO4. The
solvent was removed under vacuum, and the residue was further purified by
flash-column chromatography on silica gel to afford the product
1-(4-nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole in 94% yield. Table 4, Entry 3, yield 90%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM N-Arylation of heterocycles with chloro- and fluoroarenes using
resin-supported sulfonato-Cu(salen) complex
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kantam, M. Lakshmi; Ramani, T.; Chakrapani, L.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2008), 38(4), 626-636

$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: II. General procedure for the catalytic
N-arylation of nitrogen-containing heterocycles with aryl or heteroaryl
halides To a flame-dried Schlenk test tube with a magnetic stirring bar
was charged with CuI (38.2 mg, 0.2 mmol), Cs2CO3 (0.652 g, 2.0 mmol),
nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.4 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl halide
(1.0 mmol) and DMF (2 mL) under N2. A rubber septum was replaced with a
glass stopper, and the system was then evacuated twice and back filled
with N2. The reaction mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature,
and then heated at 120 °C for 40 h. The reaction mixture was then cooled
to ambient temperature, diluted with 2-3 mL of ethyl acetate, filtered
through a plug of silica gel, and and washed with 10-20 mL of ethyl
acetate. The combined organic extracts were concentrated and the
resulting residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel to
provide the desired product. 1-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-1H-imidazole (3a)2
4-Imidazol-1-yl-benzonitrile (3d)2 Following the general procedure, a
white solid was obtained. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.31 (s, 1H), 7.41
(s, 1H), 7.57 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 8.04 (s, 1H), 8.37 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H)
ppm. 13C NMR (150 MHz, CDCl3): δ 110.9, 117.5, 117.8, 121.3, 131.4,
134.1, 135.2, 140.4 ppm. GC-MS (EI, m/z): 169 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Simple Copper Salt-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Nitrogen-Containing
Heterocycles with Aryl and Heteroaryl Halides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhu, Liangbo; Guo, Peng; Li, Gaocan; Lan, Jingbo; Xie, Rugang; You,
Jingsong
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 72(22), 8535-8538

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Coupling of Aryl Iodides with Amines at Room
Temperature; General Procedure An oven-dried Schlenk tube was charged
with CuI (20 mg, 10 mol%), Cs2CO3 (652 mg, 2 mmol), and 3-acetylcoumarin
(L5, 38 mg, 20 mol%). The tube was evacuated and backfilled with N2 (this
procedure was repeated 3 ×). Then aryl halide (1.0 mmol), amine (1.5
mmol), and DMF (0.5 mL) were added under N2. The tube was sealed and the
mixture was stirred at r.t. for 24 h. The resulting suspension was
filtered through a pad of silica gel with the help of CH2Cl2 (50 mL). The
filtrate was concentrated and the residue was purified by column
chromatography (silica gel, EtOAc-PE). The product.
1-(4-Tolyl)-1H-imidazole (3p)18 . IR (KBr): 3126, 1523, 1460, 1301, 1243,
1110, 1053, 959, 899, 814, 731, 656, 525 cm-1. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ
= 7.82 (s, 1 H), 7.31-7.22 (m, 5 H), 7.19 (s, 1 H), 2.39 (s, 3 H). 13C
NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 137.5, 135.7, 135.0, 130.4, 130.1, 121.5,
118.4, 20.9. GC-MS (EI): m/z = 158.05 [M]+.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM 3-Acetylcoumarin as a practical ligand for copper-catalyzed C-N coupling
reactions at room temperature
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Tao, Chuan-Zhou; Liu, Wei-Wei; Sun, Ji-You; Cao, Zhi-Ling; Li, Hui;
Zhang, Ying-Fen
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2010), (8), 1280-1284

$DATUM 1317-39-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Solvent-Free, Copper-Catalyzed N-Arylation of
a Nitrogen- Containing Heterocycle; General Procedure A mixture of
nitrogen-containing heterocycle 1 (0.5 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl halide 2
(0.6 mmol), cubic Cu2O nanoparticles (5-10 mol%), 1,10-phenanthroline
(L2; 10-20 mol%), and TBAF (1.5 mmol) was stirred at 110-145 °C for 24-48
h until complete consumption of the starting material was observed
(monitored by TLC). After completion of the reaction, EtOAc (10 mL) was
poured into the mixture, which was then washed with sat. aq NaCl (3 × 5
mL) and extracted with Et2O (2 × 10 mL). The organic layers were then
dried (anhyd Na2SO4) and evaporated under vacuum. The residue was
purified by flash column chromatography (EtOAc or hexane-EtOAc) to afford
the desired product. 1-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-1H-imidazole (7)5d, yield 90%.
1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 7.78 (s, 1 H), 7.30 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2 H),
7.20 (d, J = 9.2 Hz, 2 H), 6.99 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2 H), 3.85 (s, 3 H). 13C
NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 158.7, 135.6, 130.4, 129.8, 123.0, 118.6,
114.7, 55.4. LRMS (EI, 70 eV): m/z (%) = 174 (M+, 100).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM nanoparticle Cu⊂2O as catalyst
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM N-arylations of nitrogen-containing heterocycles with aryl and heteroaryl
halides using a copper(I) oxide nanoparticle/1,10-phenanthroline
catalytic system
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2008), (11), 1707-1716

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 2.2 Typical Experimental Procedure A mixture
of aryl halide (1 mmol), nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.5 mmol), Cu2O
(0.1 mmol), KOH (2 mmol) and DMSO (2 mL) was stirred at the temperature
specified under Ar atmosphere until nearly complete conversion of aryl
halide as monitored by GC or TLC, the cooled mixture was partitioned
between ethyl acetate (10 mL) and water (3 mL). The organic layer was
separated, and the aqueous layer was extracted with ethyl acetate (5 mL).
The combined organic layers were washed with brine (5 mL), dried over
Na2SO4, and concentrated to give the crude product, which was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel (200–300 mesh) using ethyl
acetate/methanol as eluent. Entry: 4 Yield: 90%

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Compound 3a-h; General Procedure A mixture of imidazole (0.34 g, 5 mmol)
and anhyd K3PO4 (1.06 g, 5 mmol) in acetone (20 mL) was stirred at r.t.
for 5 min, and then carbon disulfide (1.14 g, 15 mmol) was added. The
reaction mixture was stirred for additional 10 min, and then halide (5
mmol) was added. Stirring was continued at r.t. until the reaction was
completed (monitored by TLC). The precipitate was filtered and washed
with acetone. The solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure and the
residue was purified by recrystallization (petroleum ether-EtOAc) to
afford the desired compounds 3a or 3h or by chromatography on silica gel
column (petroleum ether-EtOAc) to give the desired compounds 3b-g.
Compound 3a Yield: 95%; yellow crystals; crystals were obtained by
storing the solution in the refrigerator.
1-(methyldithiocarbonyl)-imidazole (3a). mp 30-31 °C (Lit.18 yellow oil);
1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 2.81 (s, 3 H, CH3), 7.12 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1
H, ArH), 7.80 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1 H, ArH), 8.49 (s, 1 H, ArH).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 2.2 Typical Experimental Procedure A mixture
of aryl halide (1 mmol), nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.5 mmol), Cu2O
(0.1 mmol), KOH (2 mmol) and DMSO (2 mL) was stirred at the temperature
specified under Ar atmosphere until nearly complete conversion of aryl
halide as monitored by GC or TLC, the cooled mixture was partitioned
between ethyl acetate (10 mL) and water (3 mL). The organic layer was
separated, and the aqueous layer was extracted with ethyl acetate (5 mL).
The combined organic layers were washed with brine (5 mL), dried over
Na2SO4, and concentrated to give the crude product, which was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel (200–300 mesh) using ethyl
acetate/methanol as eluent. Entry: 9 Yield: 90%
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the addition of azoles
I-V to vinyl acetate. Vinyl acetate, 13 ml, was added dropwise to a
mixture of 0.1 mol of azole I-V, 0.1 mol of potassium carbonate, 50 ml of
water, and 1 g of benzyl(triethyl)ammonium chloride (BTEAC) under
stirring at room temperature. The mixture was stirred for 2 h and
extracted with chloroform, and the extract was dried over MgSO4. The
solvent was removed and the residue was subjected to fractional
distillation under reduced pressure. 1-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)ethyl acetate
(VIII), yield 90.0%. bp 106°C (2 mm), nD20 = 1.4784, d420 = 1.1224. 1H
NMR spectrum (DMSO-d6, 300 MHz), δ, ppm (J, Hz): 1.77 d (3H, CHCH3, J =
6.3), 2.04 s (3H, COCH3), 6.71 q (1H, CHCH3, J = 6.3), 6.86 d.d (1H, 4-H,
J = 1.5, 1.2), 7.14 d.d (1H, 5-H, J = 1.5, 1.2), 7.66 t (1H, 2-H, J =
1.2). Found, %: C 54.32; H 6.23; N 18.35. C7H10N2O2. Calculated, %: C
54.55; H 6.49; N 18.18.

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the synthesis of
lipophilic zoledronate analogs (2-16): A mixture of imidazole (100 mmol),
alkyl bromide (100 mmol) and K2CO3 (200 mmol) in acetone (200 mL) was
refluxed overnight. Upon filtration and removal of solvent, the residue
was subjected to flash chromatography with ethyl acetate as eluant to
give product Yield &gt; 90 %.

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the synthesis of
lipophilic zoledronate analogs (2-16): A mixture of imidazole (100 mmol),
alkyl bromide (100 mmol) and K2CO3 (200 mmol) in acetone (200 mL) was
refluxed overnight. Upon filtration and removal of solvent, the residue
was subjected to flash chromatography with ethyl acetate as eluant to
give product Yield &gt; 90 %.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 2.4. General Procedure for the Aza-Michael
Reaction of Imidazole with α,β-Unsaturated Compounds Using Cu(acac)2in
Ionic Liquids. To the solution of Cu(acac)2 (0.005 g, 2 mol %) in ionic
liquid (1 mL), imidazole (1 mmol) and α,β-unsaturated compound (1.2 mmol)
were added and stirred at 60°C for the appropriate time (see Table 2,
presented later in this paper). After completion of the reaction, as
indicated by TLC, the product was extracted with a 1:1 ethyl
acetate:n-hexane mixture (3 x 10 mL). The combined organic extracts were
concentrated under reduced pressure and purified by column chromatography
on silica gel to afford the pure product. The recovered ionic liquid
phase that contained Cu(acac)2 was dried under reduced pressure for the
next runs. The products were characterized by comparison of their nuclear
magnetic resonance (NMR) and mass spectra with those reported in the
literature. 24,26,39 entry 3, yield 90%

$DATUM aza-Michael reaction, ionic liquid used

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 2.4. General Procedure for the Aza-Michael
Reaction of Imidazole with α,β-Unsaturated Compounds Using Cu(acac)2in
Ionic Liquids. To the solution of Cu(acac)2 (0.005 g, 2 mol %) in ionic
liquid (1 mL), imidazole (1 mmol) and α,β-unsaturated compound (1.2 mmol)
were added and stirred at 60°C for the appropriate time (see Table 2,
presented later in this paper). After completion of the reaction, as
indicated by TLC, the product was extracted with a 1:1 ethyl
acetate:n-hexane mixture (3 x 10 mL). The combined organic extracts were
concentrated under reduced pressure and purified by column chromatography
on silica gel to afford the pure product. The recovered ionic liquid
phase that contained Cu(acac)2 was dried under reduced pressure for the
next runs. The products were characterized by comparison of their nuclear
magnetic resonance (NMR) and mass spectra with those reported in the
literature. 24,26,39 entry 4, yield 90%
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM aza-Michael reaction, ionic liquid used

Using Copper(II) Acetylacetonate (Cu(acac)2) Immobilized in Ionic Liquids
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure B: Coupling of Aryl Bromides
with Amines or N-Containing Heterocycles (5.0 mmol scale). An oven-dried
Schlenk tube equipped with a Teflon valve (Kontes) was charged with a
magnetic stir bar, CuBr (7.2 mg, 0.05 mmol, 1 mol %), the L5 (16 mg, 0.1
mmol, 2 mol %), and Cs2CO3 (3.25 g, 10.0 mmol). Any remaining solids
(amine and/or aryl bromide) were added at this point. The tube was
evacuated and backfilled with argon (this procedure was repeated three
times). Under a counter flow of argon, amine (7.5 mmol) (if liquid), aryl
bromide (5.0 mmol) (if liquid), and DMSO (5.0 mL) were added by syringe.
Finally, the tube was sealed and the mixture was heated at the indicated
temperature (90-110 °C) for the indicated period of time. Upon completion
of the reaction, the mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature and
then was diluted with ethyl acetate and passed through a fritted glass
filter to remove the inorganic salts, then the solvent was removed with
the aid of a rotary evaporator. The residue was purified by column
chromatography on silica gel and the product was dried under vacuum for
at least 1 h. 4-(1H-Imidazole-1-yl)benzonitrile (5l):5c Following
procedure B, 4-bromobenzonitrile (910 mg, 5.0 mmol) was allowed to react
with 1H-imidazole (510 mg, 7.5 mmol) for 18 h at 110 °C. The crude brown
oil was purified by flash chromatography on silica gel to provide 90%
yield of the desired product as a white solid. Mp 152-154 °C; 1H NMR (400
MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.92 (s, 1H), 7.77 (m, 2H), 7.51 (m, 2H), 7.32 (s, 1H),
7.23 (s, 1H) ppm; 13C NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 140.5, 135.3, 134.1, 131.5,
121.4, 117.7, 117.5, 111.2 ppm.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM chemoselective, sealed tube used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

as Catalyst

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2011), 76(9), 3151-3159

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General procedure for the N-arylation of imidazoles with aryl bromides.
An oven-dried screw-cap test tube was charged with Cu2O (0.05 mmol), L
(0.15 mmol), imidazole (1.2 mmol), aryl bromide (1.00 mmol, if solid),
poly(ethylene glycol) (200 mg), Cs2CO3 (1.4 mmol), and a magnetic stir
bar. The reaction vessel was fitted with a rubber septum. The vessel was
evacuated and back-filled with argon or nitrogen, and this sequence was
repeated an additional time. Aryl bromide (1.00 mmol, if liquid), and
solvent (0.5 mL) were then added successively. The reaction tube was
sealed, immersed, and stirred in a preheated oil bath for the designated
time period. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, diluted
with dichloromethane (10 mL), filtered through a plug of celite, and
eluted with additional dichloromethane (50 mL). The filtrate was
concentrated and the resulting residue was purified by flash
chromatography to provide the desired product. Experimental procedures
for the N-arylation of imidazole with aryl bromides.
4-Imidazol-1-yl-phenol The general procedure was followed using Cu2O (7.2
mg, 0. 05 mmol), L (36 mg, 0.15 mmol), PEG (400 mg), Cs2CO3 (1.0 g, 3.0
mmol), 4-bromophenol (172 mg, 1.00 mmol), and imidazole (82 mg, 1.2 mmol)
with butyronitrile (0.5 mL) as solvent for 15 h at 110 °C. After cooling
to ambient temperature, the crude reaction mixture was dissolved in 20 mL
2M HCl(aq), and washed once with diethyl ether. The aqueous layer was
brought to pH 8 with Na2CO3, and extracted repeatedly with CH2Cl2. The
combined organic layers were dried with anhydrous MgSO4, and
concentrated. Chromatographic purification (1 % ethanol in ethyl acetate,
dry pack) afforded 4-imidazol-1-ylphenol (white crystals, 198 mg, 90 %).
1H NMR (300 MHz, CD3OD) δ 7.95 (bs, 1H), 7.41 (bs, 1H), 7.35-7.30 (m,
2H), 7.01 (bs, 1H), 6.92-6.87 (m, 2H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ 158.7,
130.8, 129.8, 124.3, 117.4, 24.0. m.p. 196-198 °C (Lit. 188-190°C
[203-205 °C MeOH, H2O]).11 A copy of the 1H NMR spectrum is provided.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM 4,7-Dimethoxy-1,10-phenanthroline: An excellent ligand for the
Cu-catalyzed N-arylation of imidazoles
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Altman, Ryan A.; Buchwald, Stephen L.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Organic Letters (2006), 8(13), 2779-2782

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the synthesis of
lipophilic zoledronate analogs (2-16): A mixture of imidazole (100 mmol),
alkyl bromide (100 mmol) and K2CO3 (200 mmol) in acetone (200 mL) was
refluxed overnight. Upon filtration and removal of solvent, the residue
was subjected to flash chromatography with ethyl acetate as eluant to
give product Yield &gt; 90 %.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DATUM 67-64-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the synthesis of
lipophilic zoledronate analogs (2-16): A mixture of imidazole (100 mmol),
alkyl bromide (100 mmol) and K2CO3 (200 mmol) in acetone (200 mL) was
refluxed overnight. Upon filtration and removal of solvent, the residue
was subjected to flash chromatography with ethyl acetate as eluant to
give product Yield &gt; 90 %.

$DATUM 123-91-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Synthesis of 1-Dodecylimidazole. A solution of imidazole (16.3 g, 0.24
mol) in dry 1,4-dioxane (100 mL) was added to 150 mL of a suspension of
oil-free sodium hydride (5.8 g, 0.24 mol) with stirring for 2 h at 90 °C.
A solution of 1-bromododecane (29.9 g, 0.12 mol) in 1,4-dioxane (100mL)
was then added dropwise to the reaction solution, and the mixture was
stirred for 48 h at 90 °C. The solvent was removed on a rotary
evaporator, giving a yellow residue that was dissolved in 200 mL of
CH2Cl2 and washed three times with 50 mL of water. After the removal of
CH2Cl2, the oily residue was distilled using a Kugelrohr apparatus under
reduced pressure. Colorless oil, yield 25.6 g, 90%. 1H NMR (200 MHz) in
CDCl3. δ (relative to TMS): 7.45 (s, 1H), 7.05 (s, 1H), 6.90 (s, 1H),
3.92 (t, 2H, J = 6.9 Hz), 1.76 (2H, m), 1.25 (18H, br s), 0.88 (t, 3H, J
= 6.3Hz).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Imidazolium-Based Zwitterionic Surfactant: A New Amphiphilic Pd
Nanoparticle Stabilizing Agent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Souza, Bruno S.; Leopoldino, Elder C.; Tondo, Daniel W.; Dupont, Jairton;
Nome, Faruk
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Langmuir (2012), 28(1), 833-840

$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM For a general procedure, imidazole (0.2 mol, 13.6 g) and acrylonitrile
(0.27 mol, 14.3 g) were dissolved in 20 mL methanol. The mixture was
stirred at 50 °C for 8 h under nitrogen. The solvent methanol and the
unreacted acrylonitrile were subsequently removed under vacuum. After
that, 1-bromododecane (0.14 mol, 34.9 g) was added with isopropanol (40
mL) and the mixture was refluxed at 80 °C for 18 h under nitrogen. The
isopropanol was removed under vacuum when the reaction was completed. The
residue was dissolved in a 15 wt% NaOH aqueous solution (100 mL) and
extracted by chloroform (50 mL). The chloroform layer was washed several
times with deionized water. The residual solvent was removed under
vacuum. n-dodecylimidazole, yield 29.7 g, 90%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A Novel Zwitterionic Imidazolium-Based Ionic Liquid Surfactant:
1-Carboxymethyl-3-Dodecylimidazolium Inner Salt

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Surfactants and Detergents (2011), 14(4), 497-504

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Experimental Procedure of N-Arylation
under Heterogeneous Conditions Catalyst 1f (0.050 g, 1 mol%) and K2CO3
(0.276 g, 2 mmol) were added to a mixture of 1-chloro-4-nitrobenzene
(0.158 g, 1 mmol) and imidazole (0.081 g, 1.2 mmol) in 4 mL of DMF. The
reaction mixture was heated at 110 °C under stirring for 4 h. After
cooling to ambient temperature, the resulting mixture was filtered off.
and the catalyst was washed several times with water and ethyl acetate to
remove any excess reagents and reused for the other cycle. The filtrate
was extracted with water, and the organic layer was dried over Na2SO4.
This was concentrated under vacuum, and the residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel to afford the product
1-(4-nitro-phenyl)-1H-imidazole in 91% yield. Table 4, Entry 7, yield
90%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM N-Arylation of heterocycles with chloro- and fluoroarenes using
resin-supported sulfonato-Cu(salen) complex
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kantam, M. Lakshmi; Ramani, T.; Chakrapani, L.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2008), 38(4), 626-636

$DATUM 1317-39-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-56-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: N-Arylation of Azoles with Arylboronic Acid at
Ambient Conditions; General Procedure. Cu2O (0.055 mmol) was added to a
mixture of azole (1.2 mmol) and arylboronic acid (1 mmol) in MeOH (3 mL)
at r.t., and the mixture was stirred for 5 h under an atmosphere of air.
The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC and on completion of
the reaction, the mixture was centrifuged and the centrifugate was
concentrated under reduced pressure to give the crude product. The crude
product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel
(hexane-EtOAc, 70:30) to afford the N-arylated azoles.
1-(4-Fluorophenyl)-1H-imidazole (Table 1, entry 7), yield 90%. 1H NMR
(300 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 7.79 (br s, 1 H), 7.33-7.36 (m, 2 H), 7.14-7.21 (m,
4 H). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 163.4, 160, 133.5, 130.4, 123.2 (2 C),
118.2, 116.5 (2 C). EI-MS: m/z = 162 (100%), 141, 135, 129, 108, 95, 83,
71, 57. HRMS: m/z calcd for C9H7FN2 (M+): 162.059; found: 162.059.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM catalyst reusable
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Copper(I) oxide-catalyzed N-arylation of azoles and amines with
arylboronic acid at room temperature under base-free conditions
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Sreedhar, Bojja; Venkanna, Gopaladasu T.; Kumar, Kota Balaji Shiva;
Balasubrahmanyam, Vura
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2008), (5), 795-799

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Synthesis of compounds 4a-4h Tetrahydrofuran (20 cm3) was added to 0.68 g
imidazole (10 mmol) and 0.29 g sodium hydride (12 mmol); the suspension
was stirred at room temperature for 1 h. Then, compounds 3a-3h (11 mmol)
were added dropwise. After completing the dropping, the temperature was
increased to 40 °C. Upon completion of the reaction, water was added. The
resulting mixture was extracted with dichloromethane, then dried by
anhydrous sodium sulfate and subsequently the solvent was evaporated
under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by silica gel column
chromatography (eluent: petroleum/ethyl acetate, 3/1 v/v). The compounds
4a-4h as white solid [18].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Design and synthesis of novel miconazole-based ciprofloxacin hybrids as
potential antimicrobial agents
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Gu, Xiao-Long; Liu, Hong-Bin; Jia, Qing-Hui; Li, Jie-Feng; Liu, Yan-Long
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Monatshefte fuer Chemie (2015), 146(4), 713-720

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Preparation of Activated Monomers. For assays analyzed by mass
spectrometry, oxyazabenzotriazolides of deoxynucleotides (OAt esters)
were synthesized via activation of dNMPs with EDC/HOAt, as previously
described.24 Mixing of equimolar quantities of the four OAt esters as
previously described19 gave solutions that were directly used for assays.
Imidazolides of dNMPs were prepared via redox condensation using
imidazole, 2,2'-dithiodipyridine, and triphenylphosphine, as described
for ribonucleotides by Lohrmann and Orgel.25 Briefly, a mixture of the
dNMP (0.1 mmol, previously dried at 0.1 mbar), imidazole (68 mg, 1 mmol),
and 2,2'-dithiodipyridine (66 mg, 0.3 mmol) was dissolved in a mixture of
DMF/DMSO (1.5 mL, 1:1, v:v) under argon. Triethylamine (50 μL, 0.3 mmol)
and triphenylphosphine (53 mg, 0.2 mmol) were added to the reaction
mixture. After being stirred for 2.5 h at room temperature, the clear
yellow solution was added dropwise to a cold solution of sodium
perchlorate (50 mg, 40 mmol) in a mixture of diethylether/acetone (20 mL,
1:1, v:v) and triethylamine (1.5 mL, 10 mmol). After being stirred for 30
min and subsequent centrifugation, the supernatant was aspirated, and the
pellet was washed with diethylether/acetone (20 mL, 1:1, v:v). After
centrifugation, the resulting colorless pellet was dried at 0.1 mbar and
stored at -20 °C. 4a, yield: 60-90%. The imidazolides were analyzed by
31P NMR spectroscopy and were found to be >98% activated. Again,
equimolar mixtures containing all four imidazolides of dNMPs were
prepared from four freshly prepared solutions of activated monomers in
water. Concentrations in stock solutions were determined on the basis of
UV absorbance, using the following extinction coefficients: dAMP, ε259 =
15 400 M-1 cm-1; dCMP, ε271 = 9100 M-1 cm-1; dGMP, ε253 = 13 700 M-1
cm-1; TMP, ε260 = 7400 M-1 cm-1.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM dropwise addition of reaction mixture from stage 1 in stage 2, substage
1, solvent ratio: 1:1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Cascade of reduced speed and accuracy after errors in enzyme-free copying
of nucleic acid sequences
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 2.2 Typical Experimental Procedure A mixture
of aryl halide (1 mmol), nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.5 mmol), Cu2O
(0.1 mmol), KOH (2 mmol) and DMSO (2 mL) was stirred at the temperature
specified under Ar atmosphere until nearly complete conversion of aryl
halide as monitored by GC or TLC, the cooled mixture was partitioned
between ethyl acetate (10 mL) and water (3 mL). The organic layer was
separated, and the aqueous layer was extracted with ethyl acetate (5 mL).
The combined organic layers were washed with brine (5 mL), dried over
Na2SO4, and concentrated to give the crude product, which was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel (200–300 mesh) using ethyl
acetate/methanol as eluent. Entry: 10 Yield: 90%
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Cu2O: a Simple and Efficient Reusable Catalyst for N-arylation of
Nitrogen-containing Heterocycles with Aryl Halides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Huang, Yi-Zheng; Miao, Hong; Zhang, Qiao-Hong; Chen, Chen; Xu, Jie
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Catalysis Letters (2008), 122(3-4), 344-348

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 2.2 Typical Experimental Procedure A mixture
of aryl halide (1 mmol), nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.5 mmol), Cu2O
(0.1 mmol), KOH (2 mmol) and DMSO (2 mL) was stirred at the temperature
specified under Ar atmosphere until nearly complete conversion of aryl
halide as monitored by GC or TLC, the cooled mixture was partitioned
between ethyl acetate (10 mL) and water (3 mL). The organic layer was
separated, and the aqueous layer was extracted with ethyl acetate (5 mL).
The combined organic layers were washed with brine (5 mL), dried over
Na2SO4, and concentrated to give the crude product, which was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel (200–300 mesh) using ethyl
acetate/methanol as eluent. Entry: 13 Yield: 90%
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Cu2O: a Simple and Efficient Reusable Catalyst for N-arylation of
Nitrogen-containing Heterocycles with Aryl Halides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Catalysis Letters (2008), 122(3-4), 344-348

$DATUM 67-64-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the synthesis of
lipophilic zoledronate analogs (2-16): A mixture of imidazole (100 mmol),
alkyl bromide (100 mmol) and K2CO3 (200 mmol) in acetone (200 mL) was
refluxed overnight. Upon filtration and removal of solvent, the residue
was subjected to flash chromatography with ethyl acetate as eluant to
give product Yield &gt; 90 %.

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the synthesis of
lipophilic zoledronate analogs (2-16): A mixture of imidazole (100 mmol),
alkyl bromide (100 mmol) and K2CO3 (200 mmol) in acetone (200 mL) was
refluxed overnight. Upon filtration and removal of solvent, the residue
was subjected to flash chromatography with ethyl acetate as eluant to
give product Yield &gt; 90 %.

$DATUM 30754-24-6
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for N-Arylation of Imidazole
with Aryl Bromides. A Schlenk tube equipped with a Teflon stopcock are
charged with a magnetic stir bar, K2CO3 (572 mg, 2.1 mmol), CuI (0.38 mg,
0.20 mmol, 20 mol %), and per-6-amino- β -cyclodextrin (100 mg, 0.08
mmol, 8 mol %). DMSO (1 mL) was added at room temperature. Then a
solution of bromobenzene (188 mg, 1.2 mmol) and imidazole (68 mg, 1.0
mmol) in DMSO (1 mL) was added. The tube was sealed and the mixture was
allowed to stir for 24 h at 110°C. Water (5 mL) was added to the reaction
mixture after completion of the reaction. Then it was extracted with
ethyl acetate (3 × 20 mL) and the combined organic layers were dried with
anhydrous Na2SO4 and concentrated by vacuum. The residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel, using hexane/ethyl acetate (1:3) as
eluant, to give an oil of 1-phenylimidazole 4a (164 mg, 98%)
1-(3-Methoxyphenyl)-1H-imidazole (4g), yield 90% 1H NMR (400 MHz): 7.94
(bs, 1H), 7.39 (t, 1H), 7.28 (d, 1H), 7.22 ( bs, 1H), 6.99 ( d, 1H), 6.93
-6.90 (m, 2H), 3.86 (s, 3H) 13C NMR (100 MHz): 160.7, 138.2, 135.5,
130.7, 129.7, 118.4, 113.7, 112.8, 107.7, 55.5 GC-MS: m/z 173.9 (M+)
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM sealed tube used, Ullmann reaction
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Per-6-amino-β-cyclodextrin as an Efficient Supramolecular Ligand and Host
for Cu(I)-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Imidazole with Aryl Bromides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Suresh, Palaniswamy; Pitchumani, Kasi
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2008), 73(22), 9121-9124

$DATUM 1-(3,4-Dihydro-1H-2-benzopyran-1-yl)-1H-imidazole; CAS No. 82746-23-4
(33) 17 General procedure C: After stirring the mixture of isochroman
(53.7 mg, 0.40 mmol), AZADOL (3.1 mg, 0.020 mmol), and PIFA (189.2 mg,
0.44 mmol) in 1,2-dichloroethane (2.0 mL) in a vial at 50 °C for 15 h
under Ar atmosphere, imidazole (81.7 mg, 1.20 mmol) was added to the
solution at room temperature. After stirring vigorously for 3 hours at 50
°C, the reaction mixture was washed with water and brine, and extracted
with ethyl acetate. The organic layer was dried over Na2SO4, filtrated,
and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by SiO2 column
chromatography (methanol/chloroform = 1/39-1/19). 33 (72.3 mg, 90%) as
colorless oil. Rf = 0.30 (MeOH/CHCl3, 1 : 19). 1H-NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ
7.47 (s, 1H), 7.34 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.27 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.22
(d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.15-7.00 (m, 2H), 6.92 (s, 1H), 6.59 (s, 1H), 3.97
(ddd, J = 11.7, 5.9, 2.9 Hz, 1H), 3.83 (ddd, J = 11.7, 10.2, 3.9 Hz, 1H),
3.07 (ddd, J = 16.6, 10.2, 5.9 Hz, 1H), 2.81 (ddd, J = 16.6, 3.9, 2.9 Hz,
1H). 13 C-NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ 137.4, 134.5, 130.5, 129.3, 129.0,
128.9, 127.0, 126.6, 118.8, 81.0, 59.8, 27.5. IR (neat) 3111, 2936, 2878,
1607, 1491, 1379, 1273, 1217 cm-1. MS m/z (rel intensity) 201 (M+H+, 30),
200 (M+, 1), 199 (5), 134 (15), 133 (100), 105 (5). HRMS Calcd for
C12H13N2O (M+H+): 201.1022, found, 201.1028.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 2.4. General Procedure for the Aza-Michael
Reaction of Imidazole with α,β-Unsaturated Compounds Using Cu(acac)2in
Ionic Liquids. To the solution of Cu(acac)2 (0.005 g, 2 mol %) in ionic
liquid (1 mL), imidazole (1 mmol) and α,β-unsaturated compound (1.2 mmol)
were added and stirred at 60°C for the appropriate time (see Table 2,
presented later in this paper). After completion of the reaction, as
indicated by TLC, the product was extracted with a 1:1 ethyl
acetate:n-hexane mixture (3 x 10 mL). The combined organic extracts were
concentrated under reduced pressure and purified by column chromatography
on silica gel to afford the pure product. The recovered ionic liquid
phase that contained Cu(acac)2 was dried under reduced pressure for the
next runs. The products were characterized by comparison of their nuclear
magnetic resonance (NMR) and mass spectra with those reported in the
literature. 24,26,39 entry 5, yield 90%

$DATUM aza-Michael reaction, ionic liquid used

$DATUM 67-64-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the synthesis of
lipophilic zoledronate analogs (2-16): A mixture of imidazole (100 mmol),
alkyl bromide (100 mmol) and K2CO3 (200 mmol) in acetone (200 mL) was
refluxed overnight. Upon filtration and removal of solvent, the residue
was subjected to flash chromatography with ethyl acetate as eluant to
give product Yield &gt; 90 %.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: tert-Butyl
2-[2-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl]ethyl-3-fluorophenethyl Carbamate
(55). Compound 48 (0.335 g, 0.791 mmol) was dissolved in MeCN (5 mL), and
imidazole (0.269 g, 3.958 mmol) and K2CO3 (0.22 g, 1.583 mmol) were added
to the solution. The resulting mixture was heated at 65 °C for 5 h, after
which it was cooled and diluted with CH2Cl2 (20 mL). Water (20 mL) was
added to the organic layer and the layers separated. The aqueous layer
was washed once with CH2Cl2 (15 mL), and the combined organics were dried
over anhydrous sodium sulfate, concentrated, and purified by flash column
chromatography using hexanes/EtOAc. tert-Butyl
2-[2-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl]ethyl-(3-cyanobenzyl)carbamate
(61). Colorless oil (0.346 g, 90%). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ 8.57 (s, 1
H), 8.54 (d, J = 5.0 Hz, 1 H), 7.86 (s, 1 H), 7.52 (d, J = 7.3 Hz, 1 H),
(7.46 (s), 7.42 (s), 1:1, 2 H), 7.40 (d, J = 7.4 Hz, 1 H), 7.15 (s, 1 H),
(7.09 (s), 7.01 (s), 1:1, 1 H), 4.45 (s, 2 H), (3.71 (s), 3.64 (s), 1:1,
2 H), 3.04 (s), 3.00 (s), 1:1, 2 H), (1.45 (s), 1.38 (s), 1:1, 9 H). 13C
NMR (126 MHz, CDCl3): δ 169.90, 158.35, (155.42, 155.02, 1 C), 154.26,
139.80, 135.85, 131.71, 131.17, 130.78, 130.57, 130.31, 129.21, 118.38,
116.31, 112.47, 80.52, (50.73, 49.94, 1 C), 46.09, (36.33, 35.69, 1 C),
28.07. MS (ESI) m/z [2 M + Na]+: calcd, 831.37; found, 831.33.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 3-Fluoro-4-(1-pyrazolyl)nitrobenzene (3f) The
solution of pyrazole (9.5 g, 139.7 mmol), K2CO3 (38.6 g, 279.7 mmol), and
3,4-difluoronitro-benzene (13.8 mL, 125.8 mmol) in dimethylsulfoxide
(DMSO) (200 mL) was heated to 90°C for 18 h. The reaction was cooled
diluted with water (150 mL), the mixture was filtered, and the solid was
washed with water and dried in a vacuum oven to give 3f (20.6 g) as an
off-white solid. Ethyl acetate (100 mL) and water (200 mL) were added to
the filtrate, the phases were separated, and the aqueous portion was
extracted with ethyl acetate. The combined organic portions were dried
over Mg2SO4 and concentrated to give crude 3f (5.2 g) as a light yellow
solid. Each lot was recrystallized from acetone and water to give a total
of 3f (23.5 g, yield 90.2%) as an off-white solid. Compounds 3g-h were
respectively prepared from the corresponding nitrogen-containing
heterocycle in a similar procedure. 3h, yield 90%.

$DATUM 7646-69-7
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Synthesis of compounds 4a-4h Tetrahydrofuran
(20 cm3) was added to 0.68 g imidazole (10 mmol) and 0.29 g sodium
hydride (12 mmol); the suspension was stirred at room temperature for 1
h. Then, compounds 3a-3h (11 mmol) were added dropwise. After completing
the dropping, the temperature was increased to 40 °C. Upon completion of
the reaction, water was added. The resulting mixture was extracted with
dichloromethane, then dried by anhydrous sodium sulfate and subsequently
the solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure. The residue was
purified by silica gel column chromatography (eluent: petroleum/ethyl
acetate, 3/1 v/v).

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the synthesis of
lipophilic zoledronate analogs (2-16): A mixture of imidazole (100 mmol),
alkyl bromide (100 mmol) and K2CO3 (200 mmol) in acetone (200 mL) was
refluxed overnight. Upon filtration and removal of solvent, the residue
was subjected to flash chromatography with ethyl acetate as eluant to
give product Yield &gt; 90 %.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the synthesis of
lipophilic zoledronate analogs (2-16): A mixture of imidazole (100 mmol),
alkyl bromide (100 mmol) and K2CO3 (200 mmol) in acetone (200 mL) was
refluxed overnight. Upon filtration and removal of solvent, the residue
was subjected to flash chromatography with ethyl acetate as eluant to
give product Yield &gt; 90 %.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Example 2 Preparation of 3-chlorobenzoic acid
(2R,3S,4R,5R)-2-azido-3,4-bis-benzoyloxy-5-(4-imidazol-1-yl-2-oxo-2H-pyrimidin-1-yl)-tetrahydro-furan-2-ylmethyl
ester. A suspension of 30.0 g (47.5 mmol) 3-chlorobenzoic acid
(2R,3S,4R,5R)-2-azido-3,4-bis-benzoyloxy-5-(2,4-dioxo-3,4-dihydro-2H-pyrimidin-1-yl)-tetrahydro-furan-2-ylmethyl
ester and 26.0 g (380 mmol) imidazole in 110 ml MeTHF was treated at room
temperature with 19.2 g (189 mmol) triethylamine. The resulting mixture
was treated at 10 to 20° C. within 30 minutes with 11.03 g (71.2 mmol)
phosphorous oxychloride. The mixture was heated to 60° C. and stirred at
this temperature for 5 hours. The mixture was then cooled to 15° C. and
treated at this temperature with 125 ml water. The layers were separated
and the aqueous layer was extracted with MeTHF (1×30 ml). From the
organic layer MeTHF was completely removed by distillation and replaced
by 250 ml acetonitrile. Water (50 ml) and methylene chloride (100 ml)
were added and the layers were separated. The aqueous layer was extracted
with methylene chloride (1×100 ml). The organic layer was filtered, the
solvent was evaporated and the residue (34.2 g) dried in vacuo (<30 mbar)
at 40° C. for 16 hours to afford 29.7 g (90.8%) of 3-chlorobenzoic acid
(2R,3S,4R,5R)-2-azido-3,4-bis-benzoyloxy-5-(4-imidazol-1-yl-2-oxo-2H-pyrimidin-1-yl)-tetrahydro-furan-2-ylmethyl
ester with an assay of 99.3% (area). 1H NMR (CDCl3) δ 4.87 (s, 2H);
6.04-6.07 (m, 2H); 6.33 (dd, 1H); 6.51 (d, 1H); 7.20-7.41 (m, 6H);
7.49-7.60 (m, 3H); 7.69 (s, 1H); 7.89-8.06 (m, 7H); 8.37 (s, 1H). IR:
2923, 2854, 2120 (—N3), 1730, 1678, 1633, 1545, 1469, 1247, 1127, 929,
709, 476 cm−1. MS: 682 (M++1).
